reviews.text:
I lived in Barcelona for two months and walked by passeig de Gracia every. single. day. 
It is filled with lively and vibrant people and many different kinds of restaurants to choose from. If you have never been to Spain, I recommend staying in this area of Barcelona as you can easily get around via metro or bus and most everything is walking distance. 

Of course anywhere you go you must beware of pickpockets but if you stay alert you should be fine.
This big street was a main passageway through Barcelona. It contains lots of shops, restaurants, and we found an excellent parking option here for our time in Barcelona.
A nice walk from our hotel and a super array of shops...some of the chain stores you are used to and some new ones..you will enjoy yourself immensely :)  :)
We stayed in a apartment a few minutes of passeig de Grácia, near the Fontana Metro Station. Walk in the streets and watch the amazing modernists buildings is always a great pleasure.

The street simply has all the best shops in Barcelona, everything from Zara to Burberry and the really high-end stuff. Even if you don’t want to go in some of the high-end potentially intimidating stores it’s a really nice place to just wander up and down. We booked a hotel on this  street which was just the perfect location to go out and about in Barcelona. You can also find some of Gaudi’s famous work on this street and apparently the most expensive real estate in all of Spain
We rode the local bus to Park Guell and then walked the Passeig de Gracia back down to Plaza Catalunya. I felt like I was walking a Parisian neighborhood onto the Boulevard Haussmann. Loved it!

Even if you don't shop, recommend to at least come and stroll along this shopping street of Barcelona. Conveniently, Casa Batlo and Casa Batlo are both on this street. Beside this two iconic building, you can find other impressive architecture building along the street as well (Casa Amatller, cases Antoni Rocamora, casa viuda Marfa...). If you shop, this is probably the first stop to check out. All the popular brands (high end to high street, ultra expensive to affordable, kid to ladies to men to sports) could be found here. Check out the Flagship Zara, H&M and Muji here!
A much nicer area than Las Ramblas with some amazing architecture and better restaurants. Less touristy as well.

Lots of shops - mainly expensive ones - but totally worth it even for just a walk. You can also admire the exceptional buildings as you walk by as it is one of the most beautiful streets in Barcelona.
Avoid, or at least be SUPER aware of what is going on around you. Gangs of them are watching you to spot an opportunity.
Very expensive shops etc on this street. But this where Case Battlo and Cass Mila/La Pedrera. Many beautiful buildings.

Lovely avenue in the heart of Barcelona. It is lined with boutiques, high-end international retailers, restaurants, cafes and very attractive classic buildings, including several Gaudi designed masterpieces. I recommend heading down some of the quieter side streets as well as the tree-lined street that runs parallel (Rambla de Catalunya) for additional shops, great architecture and pedestrian paths with benches to sit and relax.

This very wide street with a pedestrian area in the middle is lined with high-end shopping, as well as restaurants and cafes.  Some splendid building design along the way.  Further uphill you get into an interesting neighborhood, Gracia, one of my favorite parts of town.

luxurious hotel for reasonable prices. Very welcoming.  provided a tray of fruit and large bottle of water,   close to restaurants, tourist attractions etc

Shortly after we arrived we were unfortunate enough to be robbed.  the staff in the hotel were very helpful and understanding and commiserated with us.
A lovely avenue with lots of very stylish and designer shops, even if you cant afford to shop you can window shop and enjoy the scale of the architecture
We lived in the hotel 30m from passage...Love this street.It lives it’s own life,any season,any time
All the big names on this street, plus some classic architecture and of course tapas and coffee shops.

Unbelievable street with shops and restaurants.
Perfect place to enjoyed the day and visit monuments.
Our Hotel was right on this street. It was fun to walk and see all the stores. We had no problems with pic pockets but we were very cautious...a must!
Nice place to visit. It has most of the beautiful building in Barcelona city center. Easy to get there with tram or metro bus.
We loved walking up and down this beautiful street, did most of our shopping here and enjoyed the beauty of the buildings. Do not miss!
Best place I have been in Barcelona! Will come again! Amazing food and service! Book a table day upfront and enjoy! Won’t regret!
Can't get enough of Gaudi's genius, the rooftop was extraordinary and fascinating to see his structural genius as well as decorative, all functional!
Fantastic area of Barcelona. great to walk around here and marvel at the Gaudí inspired architecture.

Passenger de Garcia is a great avenue for walking, people watching, and window shopping. Walk down to the Placa Catalunya for one of the great public plazas in Spain. Also of course the Gaudi buildings to gawk at.

Amazing place to shop from low end to high end clothing.
Whilst shopping you can take in the view of the lovely historical buildings.
Plenty of nice resturants and cafes to eat at.
The tram is right out side 
I would recommend wearing comfortable shoes. I done 25 thousand steps for 6 hour shop
This is my favorite street in Barsa. Amazing. Really amazing. Great architecture, lot of places for high-end shopping. Atmosphere is so lovely and friendly. I really enjoy here. ❤
If high-end shopping is your thing, this is the street for you.  I much prefered the little shops in the areas off Las Ramblas.
If you want to shop this is the place to do it. This could be compared to the Champs élyséens in Paris.
You have to walk alot in Barca & this is pretty much like the main street. It doesn't have the tacky/tourist feel of Las Ramblas

It's a nice street to walk and I did pretty much the whole length but it is busy with traffic and I found smaller streets in Villa de Gracia more intimate and enticing to spend longer time in, Walk all the way to Park Guell if you have time, it does not actually take that long!
The metro will take you right to the heart of the area.  lovely for a day out and can access both Casa Bastilo and Casa Mila with ease!
Came out of the metro for the first time and was litterally blown away the buildings and history captivate you immediately. Wonderful place for shopping and food
I love this street. Full of famous stores and not only, great architecture and you can find a lot of restaurants. You can only have a nice walk and enjoy the city vibes. ☺️

We love strolling on this street, with so many shops and restaurants.  It has access to the subway/metro as well as buses (incl the HOHO tourist bus) and is a central location for many attractions.  There are so many architecturally interesting buildings along this street - it's lovely.

Pleasent urban promenade around luxury shops of famous phasion brands and 
also hidden restaurants like El Nacional and other many for tasting delicious tapas.
Enjoy too the special architectures gems imaginated by Antoni Gaudi and others
as Casa Milà, Casa Ametller, Casa Lleó Morera, Casa Batlló.

One can easily say that this Avenue is the Champs Elysee of Barcelona. It is a wide avenue with many elegant stores and beautiful houses. There are two important buildings of Gaudi here, Casa Batllo and Casa Milà. It is a pleasure to walk along Passeig de Gràcia. There are several Metro stations on the avenue as it is quite long.
Broad luxury street with all shops you wantb to visit. Lot of restaurants, cafes, terraces to rest a while. Beautiful trees every where.

Superbly decorated with beautiful lights, it certainly was enchanting. A shoppers place indeed for branded stuff. You can shop till you drop and then enjoy tapas at some famous places nearby. A beautiful place to just stroll and soak in the beauty of Barcelona.
Beautiful area, though the selection of shopping is no different than that of major cities everywhere...Barcelona's "Fifth Avenue".
It is the most luxurious street in Barcelona, full of A list designers stores. The buildings are so elegant and beautiful and, ofc, Casa Batllo and La Pedrera are here, so you must visit.
This rood is very well decorated with lights and lined with impressive building on both sides. This street holds two of the most famouse buildings in Barcelona - Casa Mila and Casa Batllio.

Lots of name brand, fashion, and finance institutions. Very happy that they preserved the old buildings. Here the old, the new and the modern all coexist without any conflict. There will be plenty of places to take pictures. My friend told me to pay attention to doors. Occasionally we saw these large doors leading to a foray with building settings. Everything looks amazing.
The street was around 15' from our hotel. There were many nice shops, cafeterias and restaurants. It was a nice experience
Spent a day exploring this neighbourhood by myself. Was a unique place full of character. Definitely recommend if you are staying in Barcelona for more than a few days.
This street has many good shops and also has two of Gaudi's best known buildings, Casa Batllo and Casa Mila.

Stayed over Xmas and New Year. BE-Mate Apartments. Fantastic, Local super markets selling tons of lovely stuff. I don't walk much but main sights are 20-30 mins walk. Diagonal metro is there. The bonus for me was the local areas at the top of the street. Lots of great food in that area to cater for all tastes. A brilliant place to stay ib Barcelona, it's got it all.

It is a nice area. Not to be a must one, but nice buildings and markets.
I think all the roads go there..

Our hotel was only a block from Passeig de Gracia and we loved strolling on this beautiful street with its elegant homes and shops with pretty balconies and the many Modernisme buildings. The Metro stop was handy and enabled us to reach other sights in the city quickly.

great for shopping, I take this route into downtown and never notice the distance I'm walking because the shops, cafes, bakeries, etc...all have my attention.
Lovely alleys cross this street with the unique shops, a must - turn off onto one of the alleys :)
Not my cup of tea the shops but this wonderful avenue you will enjoy. It has restaurants, cafes and shops so you don’t get bored. It’s quite busy too.

The Passeig has many beautiful buidlings, but is equally filled with high-end designer shops. I enjoyed the architecture, the street lamps with their molded seats, and the general atmosphere of "To stroll and see (and be seen?)". Shade from its trees makes it comfortable and the wide vast pavements are excellent for having that stroll. Take your time to observe the details on the balconies above, and the grandeur of the buidlings and have a relaxing seat on the many benches
This was our second time visiting this area of Barcelona.  We enjoyed walking up and down the Passeig looking at the architecture and had tapas by the Pedrera (Casa Mila)

Its worth probably a whole day to wander down the Passeig de Gracia and take in all the sights ie Casa Battlo , Casa Millo etc while windowshopping at all the high end boutiques and then going for a coffee and people watch on this busy street.
Love walking around. Beautiful buildings, friendly people. Great shopping. Right on the Metro. Easily accessed from all over the city.

The Passeig de Gràcia is beautifully decorated with Gaudi floor tiles and stunning street lamps. During Christmas time the street is lined with beautiful handing lights across the roadway. There is high end shopping and spectacular building and architecture. A must see when visiting Barcelona. The street is busy so if travelling in a group endure you allocate a meeting spot if you were to become separated.
We stayed in an apartment at hotel sixty two. Great accomodations. Staff were awesome. Shaun, george, and nacis went out of their way to make our stay comfortable and memorable. We will be back.

Upscale, chic and fashionable Passeig de Garcia is a must visit. Two of Gaudi’s masterpieces are on it and many high end shops and restaurants galore. It’s a good gateway into La Rambla and ultimately el gotic as well. A great place to see modern Barcelona. Go at night especially during the holidays.

Although we did travel down Las Ramblas (tourist must-see), we spent most of our time eating, drinking, and shopping along Passeig de Gracia. It much more sophisticated and developed than the ticky tacky touristy Las Ramblas. The dining options were phenomenal!

..and knocking on its foors of you want to. Everything you can imagine on shopping and on top, the street itself!!!
Winter or summer, but ornated in winter evening is even more!!

We were lucky enough to get tickets to the Passeig de Gracia for a night tour!! besides seeing the house and getting an excellent information filled tour of the inside, we were in for a treat at the end!
After the tour of the inside we ended up on the rooftop, where a 12 - 15 minute light-show accompanied by selected music, oriceeded to light up the pillars, spires and roof shingles of the house and surrounding buildings!! It was A-Mazing!! 
Once the show was over a Kava reception on the ground floor gave us more opportunities to ask questions about the building!!
Highly recommend!!
If you have anything to buy or just want to watch the spectacle it is all here! Shops galore as well as restaurants to suit every taste and budget.
All the fancy shops are along here, the Christmas lights are stunning, very hustle and bustle the place to get the bus to the airport

Lots of shops, bars and restaurants none of which will represent the best value in Barcelona but interesting to walk along the street and just soak up the atmosphere. Busy and bustling but big enough for that to be an asset rather than a problem.
We stayed near the Passeig de Gracia and loved everything about walking this area throughout the week.
Adore this street, with so many amazing shops and the fantastic casa Batlló it is an absolute must visit
Some fantastic architecture to be seen here along with high to low end shopping and the odd restaurant thrown in between. Good place to exit the metro and start a strip around the centre.
A good avenue for walking and shopping. There is variety of shops. But there is very often renovation and noize.

This avenue is buzzing with people all the time. It showcases nice bistros, restaurants, bars, cafes, etc. The food is very good almost anywhere you walk in. Nice shops. Beautiful building to look at everywhere. It's a classy cosmopolitan spot of Barcelona.
If you’re looking to shop, this area is for you. Stores range in expense level, and there are always a ton of people. Easy access from the metro stop, and casa Battlo is close by, as is Casa Mila.
THIS is an amazing street. you need to walk both sides to see all the buildings. Every corner has something cool. Like no where else in Europe..it is so unique...

Happened to have an afternoon available to visit a bit of the city.  Some nice shops, clean walkways but unfortunately with a nice, important street comes with it some nasty people.  Watch your wallets and bags!

Really well done. You ll learn more hear than any of the other Guodi tours. We spent a little,over two hours from 6-8 pm. Was wonderful at night. Not for those who can’t walk stairs and uneven surfaces well. Don’t miss this architectural gem full,of the cities history, including great video. Rent the walking tour. It will not be the same if you don’t. It’s REALY WELL Done!
Great place to walk and go shopping! All the great stores and shops are nearby, and also great places to eat, for example Ciudad Condal- awesome tapas!

You can buy just about anything along this very fashionable street and you can also enjoy some spectacular unique architecture, plus lots of elegant places to sit and drink coffee.  Very upscale experience.
Feels a bit like strolling down a major boulevard in Paris, wide and elegant, if brands are your thing you will love it here, I prefer the little independent shops in Born or Raval
This is a very busy avenue with high end retail stores as well as many restaurants.  A number of tours start in this area and Casa Battlo is also located here.
this avenue will "hurt"your credit card... beautiful and wide avenue where on both sides you will fine the best designers shops mixed with some restaurants and cafes terraces...worth to experience.

This must be one of, if not the premier street in Barcelona. The Gaudí buildings, the top brand retail and hotels. All make for a very nice experience. 

Small things matter, I think it was the street lights and their ornate-ness that caught me.
Very pleasant to stroll on this, Also takes you to/past Casa Batllo and Casa Mira by Gaudi. Clean and gracious feeling.
Long road with all the brands you could wish for. Is very centrally located and all public transport is easily accessible from here.
This is a nice area.  Lots of photo opportunities.  Lots of cafes, and restaurants to choose from.  It can be quite busy depending on what time of day you go.

Location was just amazing, in the very centre. Exceptionally clean. Very comfortable for 2 sharing a bad, but not the best choice if you plan to use the sofa in the dining room (bathroom accessable only through the sleeping room). 
Altogether very good value for money.
There is so much old architecture and beauty in this area.  Also, you will find some quaint little shops
Such a beautiful wide boulevard: tree lined with old and new. So much to take in! Gaudi everywhere but also a huge Corte Ingles and large designer stores in addition to bars and restaurants.

Barcelona's answer to Champs Elysee, this has it all: shops, restaurants, the Block of Discord, sightseers, Casa Batllo, Casa Mila (La Pedrera), lots of traffic, and lots of bustle.  Easily my favorite avenue in Barcelona.
Don't miss this extraordinary boulevard!  Rodeo drive 100 times over!  Incredible architecture. world class!

Really fine high end shops line the street.  I hate shopping but I still love this street because is is crammed with some truely amazing buildings.  If your're traveling with a shopper let them go crazy while you check out the sights.
Good shopping street with local and international brands..  Not much food so went in to McDonalds twice.

We were there when the demonstration which turned into riots were happening.  It was so sad to see the windows broken and the graffiti but it didn’t stop the street being charming and the shopping was just as good as it’s every been.
We were lucky to walk down the middle of this excellent boulevard without any traffic, due to the recent riots. Bewitching and a great advert for pedestrianising streets. Awesome architecture.

After all the scheduled-must-see sites in Barcelona, it was a wonderful experience to just stroll this beautiful avenue, take in the amazing Gaudy sites, the other beautiful architecture and sit awhile with young Catalonian protesters of Oct 2019.

Felt more connected to the city and it’s people.

Would highly recommend even without the protests :)
I loved it........ it is so amazing. Incredible place. It is for everybody. Attention is good too. Wow

The city’s second most famous street, after Las Ramblas. Passeig de Gràcia is one of the major avenues in Barcelona  and one of its most important shopping and business areas. Passeig de Gracia is also a great treat for art enthusiasts.  It is  a place with several of the city's most celebrated pieces of architecture here.  Usually full of foreigners craning for a view of La Pedrera, Casa Batllo and other  modernist marvels on  that  street.  Along the street  you will also see Art Nouveau  lamps  , made of wrought iron, designed by Pere Falques. In the other words  if you love sightseeing or shopping you should leave plenty of time for a stroll here.
You can walk up and down this street for three days and you will still be amazed by every building....each one of them is unique ...you just want to stop and admire one after one ...

Seeing as this lovely avenue was very near our hotel, we strolled a long distance and saw the famous Gaudi Museum [always many people in queues there, but well worth visiting] There are beautiful shops and many different restaurants along the way.
Loved staying on this street.  Full of chic boutique shops, tree lined and a wide Avenue. Perfect place to stay in accommodation if you can. Great eating places everywhere.

If you are into fashion, there isn't another place like this where all the most famous fashion houses are found. Whether it is only window shopping or otherwise, you would still enjoy have a walk. Don't miss out on the architecure.

I've stayed in a hostel on Passeig de Gracia called SafeStay and the location is as great as they come. So many shops to visit on the strip and it runs straight down to Catalunya Plaza and then from there straight onto La Ramblas. Also Casa Batllo Guadi is also on the strip too.

All kinds of shops like Barcelona FC Store, Mango, Rolex, H&M, Diesel etc and there are a few Tapas bars and other restaurants as well as hotels and hostels.
For a shopaholic, Passeig De Gracia is the "street to be at"! I love strolling this fashionable street where all the luxury stores are located.

Starting out from beside Catalunya Square here are the big money name brand shops, Fendi, Hermes, Bvlgari et al.  Plus a couple of Gaudi places to gather some photographers and some lower end stuff.  More cars and traffic than La Rambla but also less of the “have to go there” tourist mentality.

This is a great place to walk and takin in the scenery. Some of the nicest homes are in this area and you can appreciate how the rich lived in those days. The buildings and very ornate. Make sure you look up as the art on the buildings are truly spectacular. This is also the area where you can find Gaudi's La Padrera and Casa Batlo among other beautiful homes that tried to mimic the style of that day modernista.
This area has lots of high-end shops. Its a good place to window shopping. Lots of tapas bars and would definitely recommend tapas if you want to taste local dishes

We were staying very near here so visited daily. Worth a saunter through just window shopping if you can’t afford to actually buy anything! The buildings are very interesting so be careful when gazing above your not to bump into other people who may be doing the same or just looking at their flipping phones.
Browse for both local and globally known stores. Stop for tapas and an espresso. So much fun for a stroll. Must visit in Barcelona.

We ended up walking down Passeig de Gracia on the day of the public holiday to celebrate Catalunya's National Day. Lots of people around and a lovely atmosphere. 

The architecture on the street is beautiful and well worth looking at.
Definitely the 5th Avenue version of NYC in Barcelona in terms of retail shops.  There are a lot of nice restaurants and bars on this thoroughfare but most are very expensive.

A leisurely stroll on this street is like no other. Cant think of a high end designer that is NOT represented here. Interspersed in your walk are the famed Gaudi works such as La Pradera, Casa Bottlo and other amazing architectural structures. Wide tree lined streets, vendors and beautiful ambiance make for a great day weather permitting. In the midst of your gawking..be mindful of pickpockets. A sad but very true reality in this amazing city.
Lots of fashion options, many out of standard reach, but if you ar4e dying for something Chanel or Dior, go!

Come out of the station here from the concourse exit, one of Gaudis houses is right in fron of you on this wide, sumptuous avenue. Great start! Turn right from station and a walk straight up the ave brings you to the padera another Gaudi creation or turn left and enter shopping heaven as you head past department stores and stunning squares ( think Regent street but better!. Keep going and slightly to the right takes you down Las ramblas, don't forget to call in the wonderful food market.on the right a foodies dream! Turn off to the left from las ramblas and your n the historic Gothic quarter a feast for historians and culture vultures or continue down to the ramoas and head for the port and the beach. One thing's for sure Barcelona is to beat , one of the world's great cities imho
All the high end flagship stores you'll find here. Beautiful architecture and great little side streets with more treasure troves.
Well worth visiting as there are several tourist attractions along the route. There is some amazing architecture, so definitely worth doing.

Passeig de Gracia is Barcelona's Fifth Ave. Like its NYC cousin it started as the home to wealthy families who built grand homes along the grandest street in Barcelona. Beyond Gaudi's Casa Batllo and La Pedrera there are some amazing buildings to see while you stroll down the busy sidewalks. Check out the door at #96 - better yet go inside Massimo Dutti. When they did the restoration, they respected many decorative elements like the magnificent fireplace. Walk up to the top of the street and checkout Casa Fuster at the top of the street.
A very busy main street which has several tourist attractions located on it  including the Casa Batilo designed by gaudi
Gracia walk is very pleasant, with trees and beautifull architecture all around. Try starting near metro Diagonal and going down until Barrio Gotic.
Not as crowded.  Very nice shops and sights to see.  The sidewalk restaurants are average.  Grab a drink to people watch but eat off the main streets.

Our hotel was off Passeig de Gracia, so we walked it every day for over a week.  High end shops and restaurants, with tons of tourists. We visited Barcelona during Merce Festival, which was along PdG -- even more energy and excitement.  Hint:  go 1 or 2 blocks off PdG and prices drop by about 25% with same quality.

I can't say enough about Barcelona architecture and the history that the wealthy did in the city in their self promotion of their wealth. The result of trying to out do each other creates an architectural landscape that is truly breathtaking. Spend time walking around every day!
This must be one of Europe's most beautiful thoroughfares! Just walk up and down and marvel at the wonderful architecture - and Gaudí is only one of them!
Wide avenue with designer shops, booths with used books, other well known stores, cafes, even McDonald's and hotels/apartments/business offices.
This is a crowded commercial strip with expensive international shopping stores. Much like NYC’s 5th Avenue.  Nicer early morning when less crowded and stores are closed.

My brother and I were going to catch our shuttle here in a couple of days, so we thought we would check out the area, And we were glad we did. It has impressive architecture and shops galore, including some high end ones. There are countless pedestrians and cars, not-to-mention taxis. So, a tourist will see Barcelona at its busiest-----and most dangerous, if you like to jaywalk. And, of course, there are many restaurants here, as well as on adjoining streets.
Great wide avenue filled with upscale shops and restaurants.  Great fun for people watching, a meal, and finding a good glace.
Lots of diversity I terms of variety of purchasable. The architecture is amazing, really colourful but quite expensive too.
This is said to be the most expensive address in Spain. Walk around for a few minutes and you will understand why. It's simply magical.

Amazing boulevard with wonderful buildings. The architecture is amazing. There are two Gaudí buildings along the Passeig de Gracia. The area offers easy walking. Be careful to look where you are walking. It is difficult not to look up at the buildings while you are walking. We spent about 1 to 2 hours here. The Passeig de Gracia is located very close to the Gothic Quarter. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful place to stroll. Architecture is amazing. Many Designer stores and restaurants to choose from.

Go-to when you wanna shop and kill some time. Also, it is beautiful street to take a walk in. I love going from the top to the end of it. You end up in Plaza Catalunya and you are right where la Rambla begins. Perfect, no? Make sure you don’t skip this one when you visit Barcelona!

Stayed on this street at the Monument Hotel and I would definitely stay here again. Easy access to everything. Loads of designers stores. I will stay here again over La Rambla. La Rambla is way too touristy. People every inch.

offers everything that makes a shopping mall, central and easy accessibility of the shops, from high-end business, a good department store with excellent food agent and a high-quality wine and spirits department, to the flagship stores of the most famous fashion designers in the world. There every connoisseur's heart finds something suitable.
If you like high street shopping then this is probably one of the best places to go. Its a beautiful old boulevard with amazing shops and also some gaudi buildings to look at.

Our hotel was on Passeig de Gracia, on this road you will find all the major stores that you can think of, you will also find La Pedrera and Casa Batllo along with many other attractions along the way.

I love passing by this street every time I'm in Bacelona. Many shops from average to high-end, beautiful architecture, and good lunch spots for good prices if you're willing to walk for several minutes off the main road touristy restaurants.

Another must. Very nice shops and descent restaurant, Oassis Pizza and National Agora with many restaurants and bars inside, the Pedrera (Casa Mila) up and the Batlo casa in the middle. I loved this street. You feel very secure too....
It is a promenade with lots of expensive shops and very good brands. The houses from the time of modernism are the most interesting ones.
Lots of culture and architecture here.  A place to see and be seen.  All the designer stores are around here.
Using VRBO I found an apartment in this area right next to the Gaudi House.  I am a genius!!!!  Safe, well lit, and beautiful area.

There are sooo many shops, restaurants and cafes! It's busy but not as bad as La Rambla. The street is very wide and clean and there is plenty of space to walk, just be aware of cycles and electric scooters. Here you will find Gaudis' influence on many of the buildings. The metro stops here and the tour buses (get your tour bus tickets here from the information centre underground). We were here nearly everyday of our trip either getting transport or walking all the way along to get to other destinations. Go down the side streets to find little food places for reasonable prices.
A nice district.Interesting points of view,some great buildings so historic.Worth doing with guide with local knowlegde.
One of the prime shopping districts, and able to see 2 of Gaudi’s buildings, Casa Batllo & Casa Mila. Take a walk down the streets.

If you're already from a big city, it will look pretty familiar in terms if stores. The cool factor is higher than the average city because of the beautiful architecture. It's a great place to start your day and wander to the Barri Gothic, venture to the park, explore Eixample and it's tasty reastaurants, or go chill in Gracia. Sunday mornings are a nice time to go for a walk here if you aren't into shopping. Also, you can get sangria without judgement.

Beautiful, stunning, clean and sophisticated area with many shops and cafes. Buzzing with activities and energy. Our hotel Casa Fuster was one of the best we have ever stayed in. Classy, sophisticated with top level service. Beautiful architecture with excellent service.

My experience at the rooftop cocktail bar at passeig de gracia was amazing! Shaun was an amazing host who made me feel so welcome and he was so funny. Jesus was making the cocktails and they were so good. Can’t wait to go back tonight!!
Beautiful street that rivals any major stylish street of a major european city. Fancy stores and amazing architecture.
Short walk  to Casa Batllo, Casa Amatller and La Pedrera if you are done shopping for high end signature brands in Europe.
Full of shops but not so crowded as Las ramblas. A city of Old architecture, Gaudi's works can be appreciated.
A unique street in Barcelona with all the international shops. Very touristy and can be a bit dangerous at night with pickpockets, etc.
Some distance from the Sagrada Familia, this street is worth visiting to see domestic buildings designed by Gaudi.  The place is very busy but is easily reached by the Metro.

A nice walk during anytime of the day but we particularly liked it in the evening.  The lights, people and numerous places to sit and people watch make this a great place to hang out if you are exploring the city at a slower pace

Paris has Champs-Élysées and Barcelona has Passeig de Gracia.  Nice stroll from Place de Catalunya to the two main Gaudi design/built buildings (La Pedrera and Casa Batlla).  Lined with good restaurants (with patios) and good shopping.

Nice, high end street with all the shops you would expect.
Loved that the street was vert wide so you didn't feel cramped and crowded.
This is a great street to shop and people watch in Barcelona.  Watch your wallet here and at subway station as pick pockets know it is loaded with tourists.

This is a very lively street in the popular city. So many shops (did some shopping here) and big tourist attractions like Casa Batlló and La Pedrera are situated along the way. If you keep going straight, you will end up at the La Rambla which you must explore as well. We were living in an apartment building nearby so we passed by this street a few times throughout our stay, and I think you'll definitely pass by it if you were living in Eixample.

This is good area for shopping. Selection of different stores and supermarkets. I found some of them very interesting . This area is crowded of course but since it is in city center this is normal. When you want more quiet surroundings then just walk two blocks further and you can find the streets where has less people. It was interesting and nice area for me.
This is a more upscale neighborhood.  Similar to 5th Ave in New York.  Plenty of fashion stores, fun tapas style restaurants, and wide sidewalks.
Good Place to do Shopping , Dinning and Bar Hopping, Very Hip and  plenty of things to do . Good for a good few hours
It is a very busy street, so beware of pickpockets - we just saw some people stealing in broad daylight !

We stayed at the Exe Hotel on Diputacion 257 located off of Paseo de Gracia.  The area is much better than the Ramblas as it's more of a high end neighborhood.  Passeig de Gracia is a wide strip filled with stores and cafes for people to enjoy a nice evening walk and luxury shopping.
Cool place saunter; shop; people watch; eat; and be inspired by the cosmopolitan atmosphere. Of course Gaudi's works made all pop like the perfect tie on a striking suit.
The place to see and be seen.  Also a very lovely boulevard to walk.  The neighborhood of Gracia is in a gentrification mode but we loved the realness of it didn't feel like tourists.

This is my favourite street in Barcelona, it has all the top designer shops on a lovely boulevard. It has several fantastic Gaudi buildings lots of tapas bars and restaurants. I walked up and down this street every day for 10 days and saw something new every time. You absolutely have to stop and people watch here. Fantastic area to stay also
We stayed on Passeig de Gracias. The location was walking distance to Casa Batllo and La Pedrera. Multiple wonderful tapas bars nearby to enjoy. The designer shops were great for window shopping

Top shopping destination leading away from Placa de Catalunya.
Designer shops to satisfy the shopping cravings of excited visitors . Also brilliant modernista buildings such as Casa Batlló and La Pedrera . Wide tree lined boulevard stunning buildings, what’s not to like !

Passeig de Gracia was formerly known as Camí de Jesús ("Jesus Road"). around 1800 the street was originally little more than a rural lane joining Barcelona and Gràcia, which was then a separate town. An urbanization project started around 1820 provided impetus for this avenue to evolve into what it is today. Even by the early 1900s, this was Barcelona's most fashionable street. We began our walk in the North near Casa Mila (La Pedrera) and ended at Placa Catalunya in the South. What we truly enjoyed was the tremendous old architecture all along Passeig de Gracia representing artists such as Antoni Gaudí, Pere Falqués, Josep Puig i Cadafalch, Lluís Domènech i Montaner, Enric Sagnier and Josep Vilaseca. A walk along Passeig de Gràcia is another must while in Barcelona.  When you reach Placa Catalunya continue to your South East to enjoy the Gothic Quarter.
went to a lot of really great shops here and treated myself to an impulse buy at louis vutton, very good selection, a shoppes paradiso

This stunning avenue is called Passeig de Gracia (Catalan) or Paseo de Gracia (Spanish). If you visit Barcelona, you must walk up and down this beautiful road, that runs from Plaça Catalunya to Carrer Gran de Gràcia. There are lots of things to see and do at Paseo de Gracia, including shopping at the most elegant stores in the city.

Right on Paseo de Gracia you will find some of the most beautiful and famous buildings in Barcelona: Casa La Pedrera and Casa Battló (both built by Antoni Gaudi), Casa Amatller (by Josep Puig I Cadafalch), Casa Lleó Morera (by Lluís Domènech I Montaner). Each building is a work of art of a different famous architect. If you have enough time, visiting the inside of these historical landmarks, learning about Modernism, about these architects and about the history of Barcelona is incredibly interesting. 

As you walk through this boulevard, you will encounter countless gorgeous details everywhere. While you shop in the most elegant stores, at the same time you will be able to find incredible paintings, sculptures, staircases, stained glass windows, woodwork and all types of ornaments everywhere.

For example, the walls at the entrance of Lacoste feature the carved artwork of sculptor Frederic Marès. Loewe is located at Casa Lleó Morera, a historical building with a very ornamented facade and a very recognizable tempietto on top of the roof. At Palau Malagrida, built by architect Joaquim Codina I Matalí, you will find Anthropologie, and if you pay attention, you will see the beautiful details of the building at the entrance of the store. When visiting Uniqlo, be careful to see the staircase, the colorful stained glass windows and the lamp. Inside and outside, these emblematic buildings are stunning.

At Paseo de Gracia you will also find luxury hotels such as the Condes de Barcelona and the Mandarin Oriental (as you approach the Mandarin you will be welcomed, for a short time, by a large bright Blue Gorilla by Richard Orlinski).

At the intersection of Paseo de Gracia and Gran Via des Corts Catalans, you will see a beautiful fountain, the Fuente Monumental, which is decorated with lights during the night.

I think that in every visit to Barcelona, you must find time, at least, for a short stroll at Paseo de Gracia. And if you are not in a rush, don't hesitate to devote several hours or many visits to Paseo de Gracia. You will fall in love.

Gaudi buildings and shop till you drop stores if you can afford them.
Just a nice street to walk and people watch.

Passeig de Gracia is one of the thoroughfares in Barcelona containing a mixture of exclusive and not so exclusive shopping and part of the tourist circuit for the Catalan Modernist architecture. Especially on the Illa de la Discòrdia where you can find Casa Batllo, Casa Amatller and Casa Lleó Morera. Although there are many examples of this architectural style on and near Passeig de Gracia.

A very busy street crammed with shops, restaurants, cafes, beautiful houses and many museums. Not for the claustrophobic.
Really loved staying in this area! We loved being able to get out and about to see everything and it was easy to visit the sites we wanted to see from here!

Passeig de Gracia is a brilliant touch of Gaudi’s architectural genius on a smaller scale.  The outside is brilliant and there is a wonderful souvenir shop underneath, but the best experience is a tour.  Anyone interested in Gaudi’s work will find this stop a relatively inexpensive, but very satisfying way to see Gaudi’s work up close.  Get plenty of pictures from the outside.  It is stunning.  This can be all be done in half of a morning or afternoon.  A splendid addition to Gaudi’s work that is accessible on a much smaller scale, both is size and in time!
Of course, it is a matter of tastes, but for me Passeig de Gracia is the most beautiful street in the world.

This street is quite long and full of branded shops. That means lot of tourists and shoppers everywhere. 
The shops were not as comfortable as other places, because we have to queue to go in, have to squeeze, and wait to be helped, seriously full of tourists.
Walked a long and keep going until the Mercado La Bouqeria

This is the area of Barcelona you want to stay in. All the best restaurants and sights are easily accessible and within walking distance (depending on how much walking you like to do). And when you have to take taxis, the locations are not far off.
Walked from the Gothic Quarters through Passeig de Gracia and enjoyed the architectural features all around. Plenty of shopping and great little restaurants.
I could go on and on.  It was great.  Like a New York City but much less imposing.  A Great vibe.  It's a livable city.

lots of shopping and food places along this wide boulevard style street with some interesting archticture thrown in, and a nice gentle walk down to the Gothic quarter and then on to the beach. Really at the heart of lots going on. Even wne to the cinema.
During our short stay, we walk the Passeig de Gracia every day between Carrer D'Arago and Plaza Catalunya. We found various very good restaurants along the way for either lunch or dinner.
A bit overrated street, always full of people and mostly expensive shops. If you find a normal store, they are always super busy and have to wait too long.

The reception at the  apartment, the apartment itself was very good. The Rooms are big and can easily accommodate Four adults. The master bed room has an attached full bathroom ( with shower) and one powder bathroom( no shower). The kitchen is well equipped. The apartment provides complimentary Tea packets and coffee pods.Dishwasher, microwave,oven,toaster and a hot water kettle are provided.

A built in safe is also provided. There were three T.V sets but with limited channels in English.

There are two sets of keys to the  apartment which makes it very convenient. 
 
The service and care provided by the Apartment staff is excellent. 

El Corte Ingles is about 10 minutes away where one can buy all kinds of food and provisions etc.  This is a huge department store. All high end brands have their shop in this area. 

La Rambla is a 15minutes walk. Around the Apartment there are many shops and historical old buildings. 

The Airport is about 30 minutes drive by cab and cost 33 euros. 
  
Will definitely consider staying here once again.

Easy access to area via airport train and great subway connections, although everyplace worth going was well within walking distance, including Barceloneta.
Lots of great restaurants and near Sagrada Familia.

Although this Plaza/square is surrounded by high end shops..... it is also  surrounded by  wonderful cafes and coffee shops. So just sit back and immerse yourself in the traditions and culture of this wonderful plaza in Barcelona.....People watching is always FREE....Then go and spend Money........

The shops reminded me of New York City's 5th Avenue... there is even a Tiffany's.   I couldn't get a good look at Gaudi's Casa Battlo, as the facade was covered due to renovations, but La Pedrera (Casa Mila) was amazing.  Nice gift shop there, too. 
Very pleasant walk made more so by the street musicians.
The plaza is surrounded by lovely high end shopping and restaurents.. el nacional is also near there

If you want to know it feels like to die and go to retail therapy heaven. Then you need to visit Passeig de Gracia at least once in your lifetime. This beautiful street lined with gorgeous architecture is home to shops such as Zara, &OtherStories, Mango and also the high-end stores such as Louis Vuitton and Chanel, to name but a few. You will literally be spoilt for choice no matter what budget you have in mind and there are plenty of cafes and restaurants to rest and have some tapas or glass of vino tinto (red wine) in when your feet get a little tired.

Me and wifey were in Barcelona for a week and the best streets gor shopping, window shopping and people watching are Passeig de Garcia And Las Ramblas. Be prepared to spend and evening walking and roaming and relaxing. Don't be in a hurry.

The Passeig de Gracia is a beautiful wide boulevard lined with upscale shops and stores for those with excessive cash and a need to spend it. Every designer and major name in haute couture has a shop along the tree-lined grand boulevard. If fashion shopping is your passion and price is no object, then you just found heaven.

This very long street will take you through L'Eixample and up towards Gracia, so some great neighborhoods.  And you will see lots of terrific architecture along the way.  Lots of eating and coffee, plus upscale shopping.

I consider this the most elegant street in Barcelona with very nice architecture and amazing shopping and cafes. This street leads to Placa Catalunya and its main architectural highlights are Gaudi's Casa Batlo and La Pedrera with Casa Amatller next to the first also standing out!

I would propose to stop ta Diagonal metro and start walking towards Placa Catalunya and further on to La Rambla or alternatively circle around Passeig de Gracia visiting also Rabla de Catalunya next to it, all streets attractive! Consider eating Tapas at Cervesería Catalana when being close to the area complimenting your afternoon walk!
Our hotel was near the street and we had lovely evenings to walk. Since it is light during the summer to almost 10 pm it was a safe place to stroll.
Very dynamic and beautiful walk, every high-end designer store you ever heard of, " Gucci, Pucci, Fiorucci," and the like, and the Padrera (Casa Mila).
The Passeig de Gracia is a beautiful fountain and plaza, which we found to be centrally located and a good landmark for touring.
Take a stroll, day or night... beautiful everywhere. Lots of great restaurants and cafes everywhere.  Try el Nacional.
We strolled down here a few times on our visit. Beautiful street with lots of fabulous buildings. Well worth a stroll just to drink in all of the Barcelona atmosphere.
This is where the best shops and hotels are located plus some other works of Gaudi . if you like to wander you will enjoy.
It is a nice placa to visit but the best thing book hotels close to Passeig de Garcia as it is 10 min walking distance from placa de catalunya and the hotel prices are much cheaper
This is a high end shopping area that also has a lot of beautiful buildings in it. Great place to stroll and take it all in!

..as I imagine is, for all architecture lovers! Many magnificent buildings along the way for you to gaze.. Casa Pascual i Pons, Cases Antoni Rocamora, Fincas Siglo XXI, Casa Lleó Morera, Casa Amatller until you reach Gaudí's finest Casa Batlló and La Pedrera-Casa Milà. Just keep your head up high and enjoy..

Took a stroll through Passeig de Gracia in May 2019.  Lovely street with alot of designer priced shopping venues and gorgeous Gaudi architecture.  Sure beats Las Ramblas.
Plenty of eateries expecially down the side streets. Very clean and comfortable to walk.

Passeig de Gracia is a street with mostly designer shops and restaurants.There are plenty of beautiful architecture all around.A bunch of them were designed by Gaudi. The most advertised of Gaudi’s work along the Passeig de Gracia is being renovated and the facade is all covered up.Don’t be too disappointed because the street is full of other attractions.The interesting lamp posts are also the works of Gaudi.There are plenty of entrances to the train station along this street.If a walk along La Rambla is too chaotic for you , you may find a walk along Passeig de Gracia a better option .
This is really a nice street to walk on in Barcelona.. It has everything from food to shopping and of course you can buy all your gifts here..
